title: Climate Change Basics
summary: What climate change is, greenhouse gases, and why it matters.

content.heading: What is climate change?
content.text: Climate change refers to long-term shifts in temperatures and weather patterns. It can be caused naturally, like volcanic eruptions or solar changes, and by human activities, such as burning fossil fuels.
content.activity: List two local examples of weather changes you noticed over the past five years.

content.heading: Greenhouse gases
content.text: Gases like carbon dioxide (CO2), methane (CH4), and nitrous oxide (N2O) trap heat in the atmosphere, causing global warming.
content.activity: Think of three sources of CO2 or methane in your daily life.

content.heading: Effects of climate change
content.text: Climate change can lead to rising sea levels, more frequent heatwaves, stronger storms, and changes in rainfall patterns, affecting humans, animals, and ecosystems.
content.activity: Identify one effect of climate change you have personally observed or heard about in your area.

content.heading: Human contribution
content.text: Human activities like deforestation, burning coal, oil, and gas, and intensive agriculture significantly increase greenhouse gas levels.
content.activity: Suggest one action you or your community can take to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

content.heading: Why climate change matters
content.text: Climate change threatens food security, water supply, health, and biodiversity. Taking action now can reduce long-term damage.
content.activity: Discuss why taking action on climate change is important for future generations.

title: Causes & Effects of Global Warming
summary: Human and natural drivers, and impacts on people and ecosystems.

content.heading: Causes
content.text: Burning fossil fuels, deforestation, and intensive agriculture increase greenhouse gases like CO2 and methane. Natural factors like volcanic eruptions and solar variations also play a role, but human activities are the main driver of recent warming.
content.activity: Identify a local example of deforestation or other human activity that contributes to global warming.

content.heading: Effects on climate
content.text: Global warming causes rising temperatures, changing rainfall patterns, stronger storms, and longer heatwaves.
content.activity: Describe a recent weather event you experienced that could be linked to climate change.

content.heading: Effects on ecosystems
content.text: Wildlife habitats are affected, some species face extinction, coral reefs bleach, and forests may degrade.
content.activity: Name an animal or plant in your area that could be affected by climate change.

content.heading: Effects on humans
content.text: Communities face food and water insecurity, health risks, and economic impacts from natural disasters.
content.activity: Suggest one way your community could adapt to these changes.

content.heading: Mitigation strategies
content.text: Reducing fossil fuel use, planting trees, adopting renewable energy, and promoting sustainable agriculture can slow global warming.
content.activity: List one action you can take to reduce your carbon footprint.

title: Mitigation & Adaptation
summary: Actions to reduce emissions (mitigation) and adjust to impacts (adaptation).

content.heading: Mitigation
content.text: Mitigation involves policies, technologies, and practices that reduce greenhouse gas emissions. Examples include using renewable energy, improving energy efficiency, reducing waste, and planting trees.
content.activity: List one action your household can take to mitigate emissions, such as using energy-efficient appliances.

content.heading: Adaptation
content.text: Adaptation is about adjusting to climate impacts and building resilience. Examples include flood defenses, early warning systems, drought-resistant crops, and coastal protection measures.
content.activity: Think of a local adaptation measure that your community uses to cope with climate change.

content.heading: Individual actions
content.text: Individuals can contribute through sustainable transportation, reducing meat consumption, conserving energy, and supporting clean energy policies.
content.activity: Identify one habit you can change to reduce your carbon footprint.

content.heading: Community initiatives
content.text: Communities can engage in tree planting, waste management programs, water conservation, and climate education campaigns.
content.activity: Suggest one community-level project that could help mitigate or adapt to climate change.

content.heading: Policy & technology
content.text: Governments and organizations can adopt renewable energy, carbon pricing, green building codes, and disaster management systems to address climate change.
content.activity: Name one policy or technology that could help your city or barangay become more climate-resilient.
